titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the New Schools Exchange Records
titlestmt.author: compiled by Tom Hyry

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:29

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The records consist of publications, correspondence, writings, school directories, and other information documenting the New Schools Exchange specifically and the schools, individuals, and other organizations of the free school movement generally. The collection includes hundreds of files documenting individual schools in the United States, Canada, and abroad, as well as many ephemeral newsletters, journals, and other publications relating to alternative education.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the New Schools Exchange, 1978.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: New Schools Exchange Records (MS 889). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in three series: I. General Files, 1969-1978. II. School Files, 1970-1977. III. Publications, 1968-1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The New Schools Exchange records document the activities of the New Schools Exchange specifically and the free school movement of the 1960s and 1970s generally. Among files documenting the NSE, the collection includes a complete run of the New Schools Exchange Newsletter, which printed articles, notices, classified advertisements, and other pieces of information relating to individuals, organizations and schools in alternative education. Individual files documenting over seven hundred free schools located around the world but primarily in North America, comprise a large series. The records also hold a broad selection of ephemeral publications relating to educational alternatives that serve to place the activities of the New Schools Exchange into the broader context of the free school movement. The collection also documents the counter culture of the 1960s and 1970s, as well as related movements for peace, social justice, racial and gender equality, and civil rights.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The New Schools Exchange was formed at the First New Schools Conference in Menlo Park, California in March 1969. Organized by Harvey Haber and located in Santa Barbara, California, the Exchange's mission was to provide a clearinghouse for resources and information relating to the free school movement.

The free school movement blossomed in the late 1960s as hundreds of community based schools were started nationwide. The new schools sought to provide children an alternative to the public education system, which was increasingly criticized for large school and classroom sizes, impersonal atmospheres, authoritarian methods of discipline, and rigid and archaic curricula. Although the philosophies and practices of individual schools varied, most free schools were small, private and innovative institutions organized on a grass roots level. They generally based their practices on ideas of children's freedom, self-governance and social justice. The free school movement also encompassed free universities, which applied these values to higher education, although they usually existed within established colleges and universities. Free school activity peaked in the early 1970s and declined steadily thereafter.

The New Schools Exchange served as an organizing locus for this movement by collecting information and publishing school directories and the New Schools Exchange Newsletter , a widely read publication within the alternative school network. The newsletter printed a wide variety of materials including school directories and other educational resources, reports from schools, job openings and letters from subscribers. Many issues also contained more formal articles on educational issues written by Exchange staff members, including Allan Graubard, Kat Marin, Peter Marin, Michael Rossman and Tim Affleck. Haber served as managing editor for the newsletter until the Fall of 1971, when Kat Marin assumed these duties.

In early 1973, the organization changed hands once more, when Bill Harwood and Grace Dailey took on the bulk of NSE's duties and moved the organization to St. Paris, Ohio. In 1974, Harwood and Dailey moved the Exchange to Pettigrew, Arkansas, where they integrated communal living and subsistence farming into the continuing educational work of the group. The New Schools Exchange published its final newsletter in 1978 and ceased operations due to financial shortcomings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in four sections: New Schools Exchange administrative files, Individuals, Organizations, and Topical files. The folders within each section are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The New Schools Exchange administrative files consist of materials created or compiled by the NSE staff. Although staff members corresponded heavily with many individuals, organizations and schools, very little outgoing correspondence is included in the collection. The files hold a complete set of the New Schools Exchange Newsletter, the Exchange's most substantive and consistent contribution to the free school movement. The section also includes hand-written indexes to the advertisements and articles for the first few years of the publication. Compiled by the NSE staff, "Directories of alternative schools" provide overviews of free schools at several different periods of time. Supplements to the directories can be found in various issues of the newsletter. Publications, writings about NSE, and other miscellaneous files comprise the remainder of the section.

Individuals files contain correspondence, writings, clippings and other materials relating to leading activists and authors in the free school movement, including George Dennison, Terry Doran, Allan Graubard, John Holt, Jonathan Kozol, Mark Rosenman, Michael Rossman, Leonard Solo, and George Von Hilsheimer.

Files NSE kept of their contacts with many education groups and associations comprise Organizations files. Many of the organizations documented were local, regional, and national clearinghouses and consortiums dedicated to furthering the free school movement. The most substantive files include Alternatives for Education, Alternative Schools Network, Coalition of Alternative Community Schools, Innovative Education Coalition, National Association for the Legal Support of Alternative Schools, National Alternative Schools Program, and the Washington Area Free School Clearinghouse. The section also holds materials relating to organizations and programs in which NSE staff member Bill Harwood participated, such as the National Youth Alternatives Project and the National Public Radio program "Options on Education."

Topical files contain materials organized alphabetically by type of record or broad subject area. Arranged geographically, Directories provide regional and national listings of new schools and alternative education organizations. Bibliographies and Writings document scholarly and practical publications regarding free school issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is organized in two sections: Elementary and Secondary Schools and Free Universities and Adult Education. The files in this series were compiled by NSE staff while creating directories of free schools and universities. Information in the files supplements listings of schools found in the Alternative school directories in Series I.

Files for over five hundred Elementary and Secondary Schools are arranged alphabetically by state and name of the school. Canadian schools are listed alphabetically by school name at the end of the section. Folders contain correspondence, questionnaires, pamphlets, publications, clippings, and ephemera relating to individual schools. Files holding particularly substantial and substantive information include Ananda High School (Nevada City, California), Pacific High School (Los Gatos, California), Wayfarer Farm (Cazadero, California), St. Mary's High School (Chicago, Illinois), Redington Pond School (Rangeley, Maine), and Baltimore Experimental High School (Baltimore, Maryland).

Free Universities and Adult Education files are arranged alphabetically by the name of the school. Files for individual schools contain correspondence, course catalogs, publications, clippings and other papers. Files for the Free University Clearinghouse and the Free University Network, two organizations which compiled general information about alternative higher education, are listed at the beginning of the section. Most free universities were situated within established colleges and universities and were formed to provide a more participatory and student driven style of education for their matriculants. The section also includes files for many schools oriented towards community and adult education. Often referred to as "learning exchanges," these schools were located mostly in urban centers. Community Free School of Boulder Colorado, Denver Free University, and University for Man, Manhattan, Kansas hold the most substantial materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arranged alphabetically by title, Publications consists of predominantly ephemeral newsletters, journals, newspapers, and manuals relating to the free school movement. The publications were collected by NSE staff to contribute to the clearinghouse of information they established. The materials place the activities of the New Schools Exchange into the context of larger educational reform movements and they broadly document the different ideas, practices, and issues that defined these movements. The series also includes many ephemeral publications documenting other aspects of the counter culture of the 1960s and 1970s.

Most of the serials had short runs and relatively small distributions and most folders hold only a few issues. Journals for which a substantial number of issues exist include Alternatives for Education, Edcentric, FPS, New Ways in Education, Teacher Drop-Out Center Newsletter, The Workbook, and Youth Alternatives.
Several publications were produced by organizations documented in Series I and cross-references have been provided when appropriate.
